title: Chez Sollberger
text:
Cut 2-6 onions into desired shapes
Slow cook with a stick of butter (8 oz) and 1 tbsp of salt for several hours
Drain excess liquid

Dumplings
adapted from Jet Tila’s sew mai recipe

1 lb ground pork
1/2 cup of carrots
1/2 cup of mushooms
wonton wrappers (makes about 25 dumplings)
1 tbsp oyster sauce
1 tbsp sesame oil
1 tsp cornstarch (helps bind ingredients)
1/2 tsp salt
pinch of pepper


mix ingredients by hand in a mixing bowl and refrigerate for at least one hour
assemble dumplings
steam for 7 minutes

Eggs, poached — via microwave!

crack an egg in a mug
fill mug halfway with water
add 1 tsbp vinegar
cover mug with a saucer
microwave for 1 minute

rice, via oven

preheat oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit
boil water
wash rice
put equal parts of rice and water in a skillet (e.g. “1 cup rice” with 1 cup of water)
bake for about 25 minutes

Soboro

start to brown 1 pound of ground beef in cooking oil
drain excess oil and fat, then return to pan
add 2 tbsp mushroom soy sauce, 2 tbsp mirin, 2 tbsp sesame oil
finish cooking


Cookbooks

Wikimedia

title: Spanish Rice
text:
… with the usual caveat that I am going for simplicity rather than authenticity
In a pressure cooker, combine

1 can (14.5 oz) chicken broth
1 can tomato sauce
1 tbsp garlic powder
1 tbsp onion powder
3 cups rice (rinsed)

and cook on high for 8 minutes

title: Pickling
text:
These days, I try to keep garlic, cucumbers, and carrots (and maybe peppers and/or onions) always available in my refrigerator for convenience. I tend to prefer an Asian-style pickling juice (base: rice vinegar), and this recipe is adapted from a Martha Stewart post.
For each desired Mason jar of food …

title: Pickling
text:
base

2 cups of rice vinegar
1/3 cup of coarse salt

title: Pickling
text:
flavoring

1 cup sugar
1 tsp red chili paste (more to preference)
2 cloves garlic (chopped)

… and boil together.
That is, if I am pickling garlic or onions, or peppers, I only need to mix the base. If I am pickling cucumbers or carrots, then I would add the flavors too.

title: Bread, main
text:
warm water to 40 degrees Celsius (say, in the sous vide rig)
in the stand mixer bowl, combine

500 grams all-purpose flour
150 grams of the warm water
1 tsp salt
1 tsp yeast

wait 10 minutes (i.e. allow yeast to activate)
mix on low for 10 minutes (add flour/water as needed)
cover allow dough to rise in bowl for an hour
dust cutting board surface with flour, remove dough, fold into boule, place boule on surface, drizzle olive oil (to prevent drying out), cover, and rest for an hour
preheat oven to 500 degrees Fahrenheit (note: my oven runs cold, so I am actually aiming for 475 degrees) with Dutch oven inside
cut line(s) on top of boule (to help ease expansion)
place boule in Dutch oven
cook covered for 30 minutes
cook uncovered for 15 minutes
rest on wire rack
